meanings.definition: To select and summon a group of people for jury duty.
meanings.sent1: The judge is empanelling a group of citizens for jury duty.
meanings.sent2: The court is empanelling a new jury for the upcoming trial.
meanings.sent3: The empanelling process can sometimes be confusing for those called to serve.
meanings.sent4: Empanelling a jury is like putting together a puzzle of diverse perspectives.
meanings.sent5: The responsibility of empanelling a fair jury falls on the court.

meanings.definition: To establish or set up a panel or group for a specific purpose.
meanings.sent1: The company is empanelling a team to work on the new project.
meanings.sent2: They are empanelling experts to advise on the matter.
meanings.sent3: Empanelling a group of chefs for a cooking competition can lead to delicious results.
meanings.sent4: In a way, empanelling a committee is like creating a mini think tank.
meanings.sent5: The school is empanelling a committee to improve student engagement.
